- So, I was always very interested in computers in

And I want to combine these two passions,

And actually, the school I went to,
Delft University of Technology has a really big and successful group doing quantum computing
and all kinds of different platforms.

So, I started doing spin qubits, which is a
platform where you have a layered system and

you have a layer of electrodes, so you
isolate one electrode and you use the way it spins in a magnetic field to encode a qubit.

So, that's where I went from there. - Awesome. And for how many years have you been
within the field of quantum computing?

- So, it's been almost 10 years, and I'm going to
switch to biotech now, so I took a little break now

- A long time. Jessica? - Yeah, so when I got to MIT, I always loved
physics and knew I wanted to be in physics.

And then I got into computer science as well,

So, that's how it got started. - You fell in love with quantum computing? - Yes, yeah.

with this quantum computing thing, right,

- Jessica is going to do a great job. - Okay, okay. Jessica. - Well, overall, a quantum computer is a new
type of computer that can solve certain types

of problems significantly faster. And the reason why is because underlying it is
quantum physics, it describes how the world works

at the level of atoms and
subatomic particles such as electrons. For example, on a normal
computer, you have bits, zeros and ones.
I have this to demonstrate. - Can I have a bite?

- For example, this is a zero and this is a one. But in a quantum computer,
you can have a bunch of bits,

which can also be a
superposition of zero and one. And it's like this spinning doughnut because
if I asked you, "Is it zero or one?"

You would say, "Well, it's a combination of both." And we can use superposition and other quantum
effects to give us advantages in the quantum

computer to solve problems faster. - Cool explanation. So, has this all to do something
with what Einstein was working on?

And maybe, Guen, can you
relate it to Einstein's work? - Einstein, it's definitely during that time,
so Einstein was actually one of the physicists who

had really, like, philosophical and religious sort of
problems with quantum mechanics.

It's more, like, people like
Niels Bhor and [crosstalk]... - Another Dane. - Another Dane, yeah, a famous Dane, who have
laid the foundation of this work and defined

what quantization means and how energy
works at these small scales. - Yeah, okay.

Huh. Yeah, so do we have a notion of certainty
within the quantum world?

Who wants to give a go at that? Because this spinning doughnut
seems to [crosstalk] what this is.

Is it zero, is it a one?" - Yeah, so there are some probabilities associated
with these quantum states, and the goal is we want

to create a quantum algorithm,
so these are a set of instructions that you give to the quantum computer.

And your goal, when you're creating this algorithm,
is to have it so that you have a high probability of

getting the right answer. And usually, if we want to design it, for example,
that there is a 99% probability of getting the right

answer, and you theoretically know it should
be 99%, and you run it and it is around 99%,

then, that's how you can get certainty
that you got the right answer.

Ideally, we get 100% probabilities
but that's not always possible. - I think we're getting more and more used to
probability because also within AI, you know,

when you do facial recognition and stuff like that,
it's like you have a probability that this is Guen,

you know, with 95% certainty. This could also be Sarah or another person,
but we think it's Guen, you know?

So, we're getting more and more
used to computing with uncertainty, right? - Yeah. - And I think exactly this question is
what also bothered Einstein.

He said, famously, "God does not play dice." So, this was really a fundamental problem people
had, and it took a while...it actually took the hippie

movement for people to actually accept that our
world is not deterministic, you have all these probabilities.

So, when you ask like, "Oh,
what is certainty in quantum world?" It's actually a good thing that, you know,
everything is not pretty fine, you know?

Like, we have an actual...like,
it makes the possibility of free will more plausible, right?

Because you have all these interactions, right? A lot of people say, "Oh, it's nature
versus nurture, and the decisions you make in life are just based on your environment and how
you grew up and what you've been exposed to."

On a fundamental quantum level, there is this probability and uncertainty, like,
philosophically gives you this notion of free
will and freedom. - Good stuff. [crosstalk]. - Yeah, I should add a note that

it's sort of all a random probability, we can

Yeah, in quantum chemistry, we want to

in medicine or in materials. And it makes sense, right, because
a quantum computer is a quantum system,

so you want to use that to
simulate a quantum system. So, that's one of the most
promising applications of quantum computing.

- But there's also this thing about just solving hard
problems like cryptography and things like this.

Maybe you can explain that a little bit? - Yeah. So, actually, one of the sort of algorithms that

which can basically find prime
factors of a really large number.

And so, that is one

it looks at, basically, in machine learning, you have
vectors and matrices in a high-dimensional

space and in quantum computing,
the underlying mathematics is very similar. So, the idea is you can map the two together and
you would use quantum computers to speed up

some machine learning algorithms. - I think now we can touch also about the security

And the first thing he says is,

new methods that could be safe

- Yeah.

There is something called quantum teleportation,

that's one of the first things I learned in

Yeah. In terms of entanglement, yeah, so I think there

and they're actually able to, yeah,

get this correlation between the
measurements of the two qubits accurate. - Okay, awesome.

There's a lot of possibilities. - Spooky action at a distance is what
the early quantum theorists called it.

- Okay. - So, it's spooky because we don't know what it is
we can't actually visualize it mentally,

like, what's going on, but you can...there
has been experiments done, where using photons,
so something we call flying qubits.

So, the qubits that you work on when you do

qubits, so electrons or microwave photons. They also have these flying qubits where you
take, for example, a lattice irregularity in diamonds,

and then entangled that with a photon and that
photon can, then, just, like, travel large distances.

So, there has been an experiment done in China,
I believe, where they actually bounce a photon

off of satellite over, like, a large distance and
often entangled them eventually, yeah.

And there is IBM in New York [inaudible], and
they're also building similar technology, and then

there's Microsoft, and they are
building something called Majorana qubits.

It's a fundamentally different type of qubit,

of quantum decoherence anymore.

And then Google is also
developing the solid-state qubits.

- That's right. - Yeah, quantum and forecast. Okay. So, how are they built?

I mean, how do you build
this stuff, these computers? Can you...? - So, how do you build a quantum computer?

So, a quantum computer, essentially what it is,
it's a quantum device or an integrated circuit that

can encode quantum information. So, to be able to actually do that,
once you have the chip which you can create

using lithography, so conventional
lithography methods. You also need very high resolution,
so you typically use electron-beam

lithography for that. And once you have that chip, to actually
be able to store the quantum information

which is a really big machine,
it's about the size of like a closet, maybe a little bit bigger, that cycles liquid
helium in a dilute phase to cool
down the system to these low temperatures. So, yeah, so you need a few different things.

You need somebody to design the qubits,
somebody to actually fabricate the qubits, and then you need experimental team to cool down
the system and tune it, and then you need the

whole software stack on top of the, to be able to
program it, to be able to create classical register

that can talk to these quantum registers. So, you need a bunch of hardware that can, then,
interface with this quantum chip and send the right

signals to it, and you need CPUs, so you
need a regular computer to be able to

control this hardware. - Can you add something to that,
the different architectures

of building quantum computers? - Yeah, so there are many different
ways of building a quantum computer.

So, you mentioned one way and, for example,
you can use photons, which is light,

you can use trapped ions,
you can even use diamonds as I mentioned.

So, there's actually, it's quite an exciting time
because there's many different ways to physically build the quantum computer and people are trying
to, like, basically scale out these quantum

computers and see which one is the best. And at the moment, each one
has its own advantages and disadvantages.

For example, some will be more reliable
but others not or vice versa, so, yeah.

- Interesting. Okay. So, there is this thing that quantum
computers are still fairly small.

We mentioned earlier today that between 50 and 72
qubits, quantum computers, and we would like to

have billions of qubits to really
solve super-hard problems.

Is there a way to just cluster
a number of smaller quantum computers? Because if we can build, like, a 50 qubit computer,
maybe you can just build 100 of them.

How would that work? - Yeah. So, the main thing is, if you have
multiple quantum computers and you want

to connect them together,
you're probably connecting it classically, right?
- Yeah. - There's the classic communication.

But really, the power of quantum computing is the
ability to have these quantum effects, to entangle them together.

And so, the problem with just taking multiple
quantum computers and just connecting them classically is that you basically lose the quantum
effects, you lose the power that it gives you, say,

if you had an actual quantum
computer with all of these qubits. You can probably... Yeah. - Yeah, so you need something called, like, a
quantum link to be able to do it. So like Jessica

mentioned, right now the only way we can actually
connect them is classically and classically meaning, like, through Ethernet cables or through, like,
a direct cable, signal cable between them.

But in order to actually have, like,
a full range, 1000-qubic lattice,

you need to be able to take, like,
5 qubits from 1 chip and connect them quantum mechanically to
5 qubits in the other chip.

- And that's a big challenge. - Yeah, exactly, so to do that,
you need a quantum link. So, there's research ongoing to create links
between different systems, so we mentioned there's

the diamonds, there's the superconducting
integrated circuit qubits, and there's the spin qubits.

And all these systems have different ways of
interacting between each other, so there's a lot of research groups working on
creating a link between like a solid-state qubit and

more of, like, a photon-based system such that
you can entangle a quantum state, and then in a

solid-state circuit to, like, photons, which
you can, then, send over a fiber cable to another quantum computer.

But this is really difficult because, yeah, I mean,
the problem doesn't scale very well, right? Because then you have...I don't know,
you have, going to have 50, like,

cables going to 50 connectors
and imagine scaling that up. So, yeah, that's still a big problem of how you can
actually distribute quantum computing.

- Okay. So, now, we already talked about some of the
challenges, and I guess, talking about the

algorithms, maybe we can talk a little bit about them
because you can also fix the algorithms so they
don't need these giant quantum computers. Can you explain some of the developments there?

- Yeah, so one of the challenges in quantum
computing is, if we go back to the qubit. - Yeah, we love the doughnut.

- So, it's spinning but you see, eventually,
it does stop spinning and it's sort of similar in quantum computing, eventually,
you lose the quantum effects.

And this means that if you think of the
computation as, you know, sets of operations,

that means we can't do any operations because
it just ends up being a mess at the end,

so that means we can only
do a short number of operations. And as a result of that, researchers
have come up with new types of algorithms,

in particular, they're called
hybrid quantum-classical algorithms. The idea is if you use a quantum computer
and a classical computer together.

And what you do is on the quantum computer,
because we can only do a short number of operations, we do that short number of operations,
and then we take this outlet to a classical computer,

we do some processing on the classical
computer, and then it spits out, like, new things that we should do
on the quantum computer.

And then we kind of do this loop between them and
the idea is to take advantage of the fact that we have a quantum computer but it has
a small number of operations.

And it's also an open question whether this is
actually useful or whether we can do things that,

like, solve really interesting problems significantly
faster, but these type of algorithms have been built.

- Okay. I think we should talk a little bit about the different
gates that we have because I think

that's really interesting. Because once you hear about these
spinning things, and then you think, "Okay, how do you actually build stuff with that?"

And I think a lot of our audience,
they are used to like OR gates, AND gates, XORs,

and what have we, but in the quantum
computing area, you call it something else.

Maybe you can explain the different kind
of gates that we have and how they work.

- Yeah. Yeah, I can explain gate, and you can say
how we actually implement it. So, yeah, there are different types of...
- You may need a doughnut.

- Yeah. Yeah, actually, I could use it again. - The first thing is about, you know,
if you want to read the state, right?

- Yeah. So, as I mentioned, during the actual algorithm,
you want the qubits to be in superposition and

in entanglement, but the thing is, at the end,
information is just zeros and ones.

So, how do we actually get that? Well, we can do a thing called a measurement. So, if it's in superposition, for example, I can make
a measurement and force it to land on either

side, and we can force it in such a way that the
probability of it landing on the correct side is the

one we want. And there are different types of gates
that we can do before that. Say, for example, you can have the equivalent
of a NOT gate where you have...it's

called an X-gate in quantum computing
but it's zero and you can flip it to one.

You can have a gate called the Hadamard gate,
where it's zero, and then you'd put it through the

gate...I don't have a gate, but you can
imagine I put it through a gate, and then it ends up spinning. - Can you put in the spinning superposition

to keep it...
- Yes, by putting it through the gate. And then I think Guen can actually explain
how you actually implement that on a
real quantum computer. - I love the doughnut, by the way. That's so great, and then you go, "Bam."

It's cool. Yeah, so maybe it's easier to think of a quantum
processing unit will look different than a

regular CPU, right? So, in a regular CPU,
what you have is you have these...well, they're literally gates, right?

They're, like, open or close, right? So, transistors and so on. And how that works is you have that the
data flows through the gates, right?

So I have ones and zeros, and they
basically go around in, like, circuits. And you put in...it's like a black box, right?

You put in a 1 and you get something out like a
0, or you can put in a 1, 1, 1 and you get a 0, 0, 0.

However, in a quantum chip,
it works fundamentally differently. So, instead of having the data flow
through the gates, the data is the chip.

So, in the CPU, the gates are the chip,
but in a quantum processing unit, it's a QPU,

the data is the chip, right? So, you have the gates actually go to the data,
so it's kind of a flip in how to think about it.

So, to answer your question, like,
"How do you implement these gates?" It really depends on the system.

For example, in a microwave circuit, so in the
superconducting qubit system used by Rigetti,

Google, and IBM, is, you send microwave pulses. So, I have a little antenna that...it's a little bit
similar to a RFID, are you familiar with, like,

the RFID technologies? - Yep. - Yeah, so you have a
card and you beep, right? So, it's really like a small transceiver,
so you send a signal and you get a signal back,

that's similar to how these superconducting
qubits work except that they're much, much smaller and they're much, much colder.

So, what happens in the normal, like,
resonant circuit is you have different frequencies, right?

They have different harmonics that you
can send, like, similar to guitar string, right? So, I can have one note, and then I have a
higher harmonic of all these energies.

But in a quantum circuit, because it behaves
inherently quantum-mechanically, you can actually see much more well-defined
levels of these harmonics and you can isolate.

So, in a transmit qubit, I use a nonlinearity
such that you can actually isolate

two of these levels and
those are my quantum information. So, what you do is you send the
microwave pulse to excite that transition.

Make sense? So, this is kind of more like
a physics-y way of saying it but... - You play the qubits.

- You play like a...you play a program on the qubit. So, with the doughnut example, you
give it a whack, right?

So, that's literally how you would do it, and
instead of giving it a physical whack, you give it a whack with a microwave pulse.
- Oh, cool.

I see. I see where this is going. Okay, so right now, you said one of the challenges
are that we have a qubit in superposition, you know,

and you want it to spin forever until you
do something with it or you read it. So, how long will they live today or spin today?

How long will they maintain this superposition? - Yeah, so current systems,
I think the best ones measured are in the range

of, like, 100 to 200 microseconds
but those are really difficult to reproduce,

so we still have to figure out

in the range of like 50 microseconds, and I

think Jessica can give a better insight into
how, what that means for circuit depth,
how many [inaudible] it could run. - I mean, your doughnut spins longer than that. - Yeah, yeah, it does. - Maybe we just go back to that other thing.

- Yeah, yeah. - Doughnuts completely. - Yeah. So, yeah, so as I said,
it's already on the order of microseconds,

which is extremely short. And so, then the idea is, like,
how many like operations can you fit in, in that

a very small amount of operations that
we can do in those few seconds or microseconds. - Mm-hmm. Okay, good.

implementation of these physical computers?

And how do you deal with the errors
and imperfections of those computers? - Yeah, so there's a whole field...like the one I
mentioned, a theory called quantum error

correction, which I don't understand. It's a Holy Grail and it deals with, like,
how to fix quantum errors.
I don't know if you're working in the field. - Yeah, I can totally look about that.

Okay, so we got a excellent qubit,
and when I talk about the quantum algorithms

and this qubit, I'm not sure if [inaudible] to a
logical qubit, so I'm assuming this qubit is perfect.

So, when I put it through the Hadamard gate,
it ends up spinning 100% of the time, when I put it through a flip gate,
it ends up flipping it.

But what happens is when you
actually build this in the hardware,

it's not happening, it doesn't happen like that. So, what we want to do is we can actually add more
qubits, so this is what quantum error correction

does is we're basically...let's say, we now have
three qubits, and these three qubits actually, sort

of, represent one qubit. So, it allows us to basically detect an error if it
happens, and then correct the error.

And there are a whole bunch of errors,
for example, if I put it through the X-gate,

an error might happen that I put it
through the X-gate but it ends up still zero, that's an error because it should be flipping it.

Or there are other types of errors...or the other
types of errors, you can say, are to just, to do with

noise, which is this idea of eventually, it's just
going to stop spinning, and so if you're doing

computation farther down the line,
there's, like, errors now where it just ends up not
being fully perfect. - Okay, thank you. So, what already works today?

I mean, what can you actually
do with a quantum computer today? What is the most practical
application that you can do?

- That's a great question. I don't know, actually. So, I think the most, like, prominent application
I've seen so far is understanding

classical algorithms better. Which is a little bit like...it's sort of sounds
like it defeats the purpose, but I don't actually

think it does. So, there is this really talented
researcher, her name is Ewin Tang,

who shook up the quantum community, they're,
you know, like, people are upset about this.

She wrote two papers about two different...or about
quantum algorithms but implemented them

classically, and she outperformed the original
classical equivalence using another classical

algorithm that was inspired
by a quantum algorithm, right? So, you can take this negatively and say,
"Oh, yeah, we don't need quantum computers,

so this is nonsense," right? Or you could say, like, "Look, actually, studying
these systems gives us better insight into how

to solve classical problems." You should look at it from a very different
perspective. You basically, you take problems that

you would normally just walk through one by one,
and you actually map them onto something like a

wave function, like a probability,
so you think about the problems differently. I think that's now the most practical application.

- And then you just have to give one example
of what you can actually do with it. - So, the thing is...yeah, so people are asking me
like, "Well, look, you can actually run a lot of

different types of algorithms on a real quantum,"
you can run machine learning algorithms on a quantum computer.

The only thing is, it's, like, limited, right? Like, you can run Grover's search, which is the
one where you can search for a number

in a square root of the
number of entries that you have. You can run a very small example of Shor's
algorithm, I think there's actually a recent

announcement that, you know, they hit a
larger limit in terms of the prime factors. So, you can actually run a lot of algorithms,
the only thing is, it's all limited in terms of you

have a limited number of qubits, and so you can't do
anything that you cannot do on a classical computer

at the moment. People are working on this to try and
actually do something that would be very difficult

to do on a classic computer but
do it on a quantum computer. - So, what do you call the moment where you
actually can beat a classical computer
calculating a problem? - So, there's actually multiple terminology for this.

Okay, so there's a quantum speed up, which says
that, for example, if you have an algorithm running

in exponential time and you run it in polynomial
time, then, you get exponential speed up,

a quantum speed up. You can also say quantum advantage where
that is you get quite a bit of advantages

from a particular algorithm. And there's another terminology called quantum
supremacy, and this is a bit more specific, but it

says, "If we were to run something on a quantum
computer, would it outperform the best classical

hardware running this task?" And this is something that Google, for example,
is trying to get out there because they said, "Oh,

we're going to do this quantum supremacy
experiment," and people are waiting, "When is it coming?" So... But the thing is that might not actually be a useful
problem, and I think the problem they're working on

is not actually...like, could you use it on...? People don't know any applications of it,
but it would probably be possible within, hopefully,

like, the next year or, like, month, or I don't know. - So, you're talking about a few
